comments.commentBody: There was an awful lot that George W. Bush never understood.

This editorial wanders all over the troubled map of Iraq. Beginning with a claim of a dangerous and unauthorized war escalation by the US, it then highlights the terrible aftermath of previous Shiite militia led counteroffensives, inflicted on local Sunni civilians. Finally, it prescribes further policing actions the US should take to protect minorities. I'm not sure what the Editorial is calling for: evacuate, escalate or just sink further into the mire of Middle Eastern sectarian strife.

I heard a top US general today say he was happy to have the Shiite militias leave the Tikrit fight to the Sunnis. Without the incompetent, corrupt generals appointed by al Maliki, they might actually be able to make progress against ISIS.
Saudi Arabia is intervening in Yemen to protect its Al Queda and ISIS allies. The US needs to cultivate better friends.

So, essentially, Egypt is our proxy fighter in Yemen. We send Egypt somewhere around 2 billion in aid every year, most of which is used by their military, which runs the country. We were forced to withdraw a number of our Spec Ops forces there recently due to Houthi rebel successes, and the next thing you know, Egypt is filling the breach for us. Just how much of the Middle East will become up for grabs in the next 20 years is an open question. All the major world power players are getting involved, including China. This should be fun. Look for the U.S. to spend many more trillions of tax payer dollars in this region before it is all said and done.

All of them deserve each other.

I just wish we have the courage and the discipline to stay out of it.
When we are aligning with Saudi Arabia, which is the root cause of extreme ideology in Muslim world, in a sectarian war, there is something terribly wrong with this picture of our priorities.

As a 75 year old, what I have noticed is that: (1) it never seems possible to create a truly democratic government in any country where religious zealots predominant and religious ideology is paramount, or where are different factions of such religious zealotry; (2) so called democracy will not work well unless there is a large middle class (3) human history (including Biblical history) shows that for thousands of years almost all countries were governed by either monarchs or dictators; and (4) attempts by any country to meddle with how another country is governed does not work out well for either country.

Thanks, Matthew. Apparently, the Egyptians and the Saudis were supporting different sides in the North Yemen Civil war with the USSR and the US backing Egypt and Saudi Arabia, respectively. Good summary here:

"The Complete Idiot's Guide to Understanding Saudi Arabia" By Colin Wells
That was an insane clue.

Here we go again, the ugly Americans being blamed. Yeah, Georgie W, Cheney, Rove and Rumsfeld got the ball rolling with a prelude done by G. H.W. and the oil opportunists.  The average American has nothing to do with what is going on in the Middle East and the anger and animosity between Israel, Palestinians and Iran was not created by the average American.  It's the good old Military Industrial Complex, GOP hawks and right wing Christians who have contributed to the fetid atmosphere of the Middle East. I can honestly say that I have no desire to ever visit the Middle East or Africa. I can't see anything peaceful about Islam or the tribal strife of Middle East and Africa. We are far from perfect in the US, but I'd rather stay put. Can't help but wonder if WIII is brewing and will start in the Middle East.
No. For a world war, there needs to be at least two major powers fighting. Who would they be?
How do the Israelis feel about this "idea"?

Shocking coordination, or the unseen hand of the US? What is the likelihood that all the US allies against freedom and democracy decided to attack a group allied with Iran at precisely the same time?

Just don't be too surprised when a new Islamic revolution takes shape and sweeps away all the old emirates and royals.

Your first question is an excellent one, Dan, and the answer is simple: We are the most potent destabilizing force in the Middle East. Obama knows it would look ridiculous if he accused Iran of doing the same thing. We've elevated destabilization to an art form. Nobody else can hold a candle to our epic skills.

The Houthis are the most effective Al Qaeda and ISIS fighters in Yemen. More effective than puppet president Hati and more effective than U.S. drones. Perhaps General Dynamics and Raytheon don't like the Houthis doing their work for pennies on the dollar. Perhaps fighting Al Qaeda, ISIS, and Sunni extremism isn't an "overriding" interest. In fact, our actions in Yemen prove fighting Sunni extremist terrorism not the overriding interest.

This is where our conflict of moral interests kicks in with Saudi Arabia. Americans are so sick of Saudi Arabia and Israel directing our foreign policy and turning us into pretzels on the world stage.

People like WWII movies for the moral clarity. Our grandchildren will watch movies about Saudi citizens attacking us on Nine Eleven, secret redactions, wars against the wrong counties, Fed chairmen admitting the wars are about the oil, knocking out Gaddafi, at Saudi Arabia's demand, to make room for more extremism, trying to knock out Assad in assistance, again, to Saudi and ISIS. Then, finally bombing the poor and downtrodden Houthis as they rain down on ISIS and AQ.

No clarity. We look like a contractor. What kind of people will our grandchildren be?

This article failed to mention one of the most important factors about the threat posed to those nations by the Houthi takeover. And that is that they took control of the Bab-el-Mandeb strait. That narrow strait controls access to the Red Sea. This means that Iran can shut down the Suez canal and thereby all of the ships carrying not just Saudi oil, but world shipping. So Iran can hold not just them, but all of the world hostage.

He was not thinking about the other passengers? Are you kidding?
No amount of rationalizing or speculative analysis can explain away this man's behavior. He was either severely mentally ill or totally evil.

Democrat: I am a psychologist and teach forensic psychology; I am not wildly speculating. Nor am I rationalizing away anything. It is still a terrible thing, a crime that was committed. I am merely pointing out the possibility of a person being so self-absorbed about a personal situation that they do not think of others. If one is consumed with emotion, it is possible to commit a dangerous and impulsive act.

What we do know is that we were not in the co-pilot's mind and we will never know, but I am sure authorities are checking into his private life to see if anything disturbing had happened, a precipitating even that set this off rather than an on-going mental illness (although they are not mutually exclusive).

There is the possibility that it was a planned suicide that was brewing for a while, but it may have been more spontaneous. Perhaps something happened just a few hours before in Lubitz's personal life, such as a break-up or argument with family or loved one, and he just thought to kill himself once the pilot left the cabin. If so he may have been so self-absorbed he didn't think about the other passengers.

It's laughable--how many Americans can find Yemen on a map?
Although Obama seems to try to meddle, he just doesn't seem very good at it (But who can say with a straight face that Reagan's Iran-Israeli-Somozista Nicaraguan oligarchas missles, money and hostages, was a well-thought out brilliantly executed op? )--
In fact, this is a good thing (for US citizens)-- as it's such a jumble now that even a cartoon version of the competing interests wouldn't get through to the rapidly increasing cadre of LIV, who won't be able to figure out who the US neocons et al. ought to pass out the trunks of cash to.
I can hardly wait to see another Arab army (Egypt), armed , trained, and probably led by US mercenaries take the field against a formation which will actually shoot back.
Let 'em go at it--Shias vs Sunnis, Iran vs Saudi Arabia. Israel vs whomever. the other upside to mutual destruction is that western intelligence should get an idea of the capabilities of the sueviving formations.
We are facilitating the terrorists. Sunni Islam running our foreign policy.

According to Ahmed Addaghashi, a professor at Sanaa University, the Houthis began as a theological movement that preached tolerance and peace that held a considerably broad-minded educational and cultural vision. (source wiki)

Houthis who are indigenous, are fighting Al Qaeda in Yemen. There is no sign of Iranian involvement, despite what our elected officials claim. Houthis have been fighting their government since 2004. Our so-called allies are siding with Al Qaeda with our approval, and now talk of invading.

In Syria and Iraq, we are fighting ISIS, Al Qaeda, Nusra Front, and other Sunni terrorist groups, same groups our allies are helping in Yemen.

Why is a coup in Libya, Ukraine, Syria (we tried) acceptable, but a coup in Yemen is not and warrants a war? Because terror supporters are afraid of losing their thrones.

The reason why our foreign policy is struggling is that we call states whose interests are direct opposite of ours allies, and states that should be our allies, enemies. At a minimum, we should acknowledge that none of them are our allies.

She also had the political cover of other democratic votes.  I just know hindsight is 20/20.  it wasn't just the US "knowing" they were out there somewhere.  If the Iraqi regime didn't play games with the UN inspections, there might have been a different outcome as well.  By the way, what happened to the weapons he used against the Iranians and Kurds?  Did he use them all up so there weren't any to be found?

Of course, that creates a new risk of a homicidal ground controller deliberately taking charge of and crashing a plane... Which illustrates the point that any system you design with no matter how many layers of security and fallback options will ultimately have either a human or a computer in charge, and both of Lee options carry some risks.

This tragedy of mass murder is not only devastating, but eye-opening. "With great power comes great responsibility." Individuals who have many lives in the palm of their hands should not only be psychologically evaluated in training, but after training -- again, and again, and again! It is extremely unfortunate on the happenings of this dreadful morning, but the occurrence will allow for all countries to reassess their security protocols in the aviation industry.

But a 27 year old could already be in the military for nearly a decade.  Twenty-seven year olds are not children...they aren't even adolescents.  They are in the prime of their healthy lives as ADULTS and much less likely to have the health problems that could also be fatal for a pilot and all those on board an aircraft.  It is just a shame that this particular 27 year old had an illness that does not discriminate based on age.

In the past commercial pilots were seen as archetypes of psychic well being. Everything to live for. But the explosion in air travel has exploded the size of this "work force". It's different, & I fear you're onto something.

People really need to stop throwing the word "sociopathy" around without clarity about its meaning. "Terrible anger" isn't what motivates sociopaths, and there's no reason to think they aren't just as freaked out as anybody when the plane they're on is heading straight for the side of a mountain. Sociopathy doesn't explain every crime or tragedy.
